column5: pp. 696-697). Whitman belonged to the third category. Though born on a Long Island farm
column6: he discovered at an early age that the city fed his soul. When his parents moved back to the country in 1833
column7: the fourteen-year-old boy decided to stay on alone in Brooklyn and work in the printing industry. An employer helped him acquire a card for a circulating library; on his own
column8: he started attending the theater and participating in a debating society. Looking for work during difficult times
column9: Whitman left New York during his late teens and early twenties to teach school on Long Island. He disliked the job and eagerly returned to the world of city journalism in 1841. Until 1848 Whitman bounced from one Brooklyn or Manhattan publisher or newspaper to the next; he reported on local news
column11: and wrote his own fledgling poems and short stories. When he was fired from his editorship of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle in 1848
column12: Whitman made an impetuous decision to try working in New Orleans. Not surprisingly
column13: the now-confirmed New Yorker was back within three months. Later that year
column14: Whitman secured his position in his beloved Brooklyn by buying a Myrtle Avenue lot and building a home on the site (with a printing office and bookstore on the first floor). Though he sold this property in 1852

Steady the roar of the gale
Shouts of demoniac laughter fitfully piercing and pealing
Out in the shadows there milk-white combs careering
On beachy slush and sand spirts of snow fierce slanting
Where through the murk the easterly death-wind breasting
Through cutting swirl and spray watchful and firm advancing
(That in the distance! is that a wreck? is the red signal flaring?)
Slush and sand of the beach tireless till daylight wending
Along the midnight edge by those milk-white combs careering
That savage trinity warily watching."|"Leaves of Grass"|"Walt Whitman"

column1: 18:55|1855|"Twenty-three poems written by Whitman were published before 1855. The awkwardness of Whitman’s language and the conventional rhyme schemes and imagery will surprise anyone familiar with the energy and independence of his mature verse. Some of these pieces (like “The Death and Burial of McDonald Clarke” and “Young Grimes”) are directly imitative of popular poems of the time; others (“The Mississippi at Midnight”) are sensationalistic; still others (“Our Future Lot
column2: ” “The Punishment of Pride”) are didactic or overtly pious. One senses the insecurities of Whitman as man and artist: Trying so hard to please the average reader of New York’s penny-daily newspapers
column3: he has forgotten himself and his own voice."|"Leaves of Grass"|"Walt Whitman"

12:00|Noon|"76 (p. 502) Autumn Rivulets: Like the three clusters that followed it in 1881 (“Whispers of Heavenly Death
column4: “Autumn Rivulets” has a title that reflects the poet’s sense of impending death. His personal history provides a clear indication of why mortality was so much on his mind at this time. Beginning in his fifties
column5: Whitman was plagued with health problems and emotional trials: He suffered a paralytic stroke in January 18 and his mother died in May of that year; he became involved in an ill-fated relationship with Harry Stafford in 1876; and he was taken ill again in 1879 while traveling west."|"Leaves of Grass"|"Walt Whitman"

column1: 12:00|Noon|"96 (p. 595) From Noon to Starry Night: The idea of the title begins with the high noon described in the first poem (”Thou Orb Aloft Full-Dazzling“) and ends with the vision of ”A Clear Midnight“ (p. 617). The poems also follow Whitman’s career from his ”noon“ on through the evening of his life
column2: with poems selected from the First Edition as well as new works for 1881. In addition to a feeling of time that has passed
column3: these poems convey a sense of great distances crossed: from south to north
column5: and back to Whitman’s beloved Mannahatta."|"Leaves of Grass"|"Walt Whitman"

column1: 12:00|Noon|"108 (p. 618) Songs of Parting: As the title suggests
column2: the themes of this cluster are death and departure: The poet glances backward
column3: but also ponders his legacy and the future of America. Just as this title is a more forthright statement of Whitman’s feelings of mortality than are “Autumn Rivulets
column5: ” and “From Noon to Starry Night” (the other three newly organized clusters in the 1881 Leaves of Grass)
column6: the poems in this cluster focus more directly and intensely on the themes of death and swiftly passing time."|"Leaves of Grass"|"Walt Whitman"
